author: yokem55
content:
What we saw during the first, failed attempt to launch holesky was that with about 20-30% online validators, and 1.4M in the set, the active validators were bleeding out only marginally slower then the offline validators. And even if we were still online when the offline folks reached the ejection balance, they still would have to go through the exit queue before being removed from the active set.

That would have taken months, during which time the online validators would also have reached the ejection balance and placed in the exit queue. It was a death spiral.

This means there is a 'minimum viable minority' needed to keep a chain alive in such a split. What size that minimum minority is depends on the number in the set at the time of the split and attestation packing efficiency and the health of the p2p network.

author: sky.cactus
content: It feels like a pretty critical design flaw if a correct minority cannot "keep the lights on" so to speak.

author: sky.cactus
content: If raising the validator balance or decreasing rewards, or increasing block time is necessary to achieve this, I feel like we should do it.

author: sky.cactus
content: Liveness is, arguably, one of the most critical pieces of Ethereum and if there is a known liveness failure case, especially one that can be introduced as simply as through a single client bug, it seems like it should be addressed ASAP.

author: jgm
content:
I suggested a long time back that each validator could have its own inactivity leak rather than making it chain-wide, that would keep the numbers low for validators that are even partially active during an inactivity leak.

But we do have to accept that the chain is a common effort, and if some validators misbehave then all suffer.  This is already true, as rewards even when the chain is not in inactivity leak are dependent on overall validator participation.  I don't think that this is a disincentive to become a validator, but an incentive to validate as well as possible at all times.

author: sky.cactus
content:
We have two examples (potuz and I) where our behaviors are not what is desired communally because of individual incentives.
A. Potuz runs Geth partly because he recognizes that in a Geth-bug chain split, running a minority client won't actually protect him from financial losses.
B. I don't run a validator at all partly because I know I can suffer significant losses caused by other validators misbehaving (e.g., they allowed a Geth supermajority).

author: sky.cactus
content: While it would be great if people were willing to altruistically put up 32 ETH and do the right thing for the greater good even when it was risky, hard, or inconvenient, I think the reality is that individual incentives are ultimately what drive behavior, not collective incentives.

author: jgm
content:
I'd be interested to dig into the idea that 90% of validators going offline would heavily impact the other 10%.  Although there are only 10% of the blocks in which to put an attestation, there are only 10% of the attestations to fit in said blocks.  And if I remember correctly then as long as an attestation for a validator is included somewhere in the epoch it does not get hit with the inactivity leak, so its loss should be far less than the leaking validators.

I think the biggest factor would be the lack of attestation aggregators on the network, and related the p2p links between them.  But if that is true then it's also a positive story, because for every % reduction of the majority client the network will recover more quickly and active validators will have less of a hit.  The 1/3 and 2/3 numbers are important, but so is every number inbetween.

I'm sure there is a % of inactive validators where the network basically falls apart, but it's likely a dynamic number on various fronts and so attempting to reach a better distribution between clients is always going to be positive.

So one block should be able to carry attestations for 8 slots which would require only 4 honest proposals per epoch to accommodate all attestations and should accommodate all attestations if participation rate is > 12.5%

author: potuz
content: A couple of comments: while there would be 10% of attestations as <@144468805697929216> says, they'll be for different heads and not aggregatable. 2) it's pretty hard to even find aggregators and people subscribed to your subnet if there's 10% online. 3) there's no timely head penalty <@792822129019584562> 4) many attestations would fail timely source

author: jgm
content:
Bear in mind that costs-wise the penalty during inactivity leak is pretty much binary: if your attestation is included, even if you miss head and source, the penalty will be minor compared to the inactivity leak penalty (as the leak progresses, anyway).

But yeah, I think the biggest one is the inability to find aggregators. It would be interesting to run some numbers to work out at what %/number of validators being offline would result in a (near-) complete inability to aggregate.

author: potuz
content: The problem is the large number of different attestations, even if some are partially aggregated or magically reach the proposer, this won't have space to pack so many different attestations from different heads and aggregation bits. I don't think 7549 cuts it <@425572898787426305> as we don't have perfect aggregation ever

author: potuz
content: There's contentious numbers about this. Attestation processing is far from being the bottleneck, and I'd be in for doubling the attestations in a block. Aggregation is particularly slow in Prysm, but in block processing, attestation processing is not that bad. The worst impact is in adding the latest votes to forkchoice, but I think even doubling block capacity this won' t change as eventually most attestations make it to FC anyway. I think doubling attestation capacity in blocks is a nobrainer if validator reward is something we care about. From the point of view of safety and resilience of the network I don' t see this as an urgent change, since we can always survive these events.

author: djrtwo
content: as discussed with <@555483069038198827> in some DMs, another place to get some gains here is to extend 7549 to allow for cross-committee on-chain aggregation. Essentially add a list of bitlists to the outer attestation, where each sub-list is at the index of the current "committee index" construction

author: djrtwo
content: although this ups 7549 relative complexity, I do believe that absolute complexity would still be very low

author: djrtwo
content: that is -- this is a way to lower on-chain data requirements of attestations, thus making the argument to increase attestation inclusion limits easier to swallow on that axis
